bibl.title: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Wickliffe Rose, December 19, 1922

div1.p: Carter discusses recent cases of yellow fever.

div1.head: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Wickliffe Rose, December 19, 1922
div1.opener:
I. H. B.
Mobile
/LC
2121 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.,
December 19, 1922.
Dr. Wickliffe Rose,
General Director,
International Health Board,
61 Broadway,
New York, N. Y.
Dear Doctor Rose:
div1.p:
Referring to the letter of the Medical Director of the Stand-
ard Oil Company, inclosed in yours of the 16th. inst., just re-
ceived, I would say that the case is closely analogous to one in
1899:--

A French nun, from Brest, arrived in New York and took
passage, by one of the Ward Line--the Vigilancia, as I remember,
for Havana. She was taken off the vessel, sick one day of yellow
fever, when she reached Havana by Rosenau. No other case occur-
red on this vessel. She was evidently infected enroute from New
York. The infecting Stegomyia was either raised aboard or came
aboard at Vera Cruz or Havana on the trip up to New York. The
first implies some other cases of yellow fever aboard, not recog-
nized, in the early part of the last voyage, from which the insect
received its infection: For the second, one could explain the non-
occurrence of other cases by (a) the infecting insect coming a-

board recently infected, but not yet infective, the period of ex-
trinsic incubation not passing until about the time to return from
New York, or (b) that during the period she was infective, she fed
only on upon people immune to yellow fever. Here we must take into
consideration the fact that we cannot say that every bite of an in-
fected insect conveys yellow fever even to one susceptible to it.

Naturally too, an uninfected mosquito going aboard could have
been infected by cases occurring aboard just as the one raised aboard
which I have considered.

Our judgment of the probabilities of this case was that an in-
fected mosquito--not yet infective--had come aboard at Havana.

Such cases are extremely rare. This is the 2dfourth of which
